STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 15, 2024
Jennifer Keller
WOLVERINE HUMAN SERVICES AFTERCARE
20300 Superior Rd, Suite 140
Taylor, MI, 48180-6302
Re: License #: CB820201514
SI #: 2025SIC0000083
Dear Jennifer Keller:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
Description child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care clients were not seen as required in the month of
October 2024.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on November 7,
2024. She stated the agency has had some staffing changes
recently and does not believe face-to-face contact was made with
all foster care youth. There were two staff who were terminated on
October 22, 2024, and she does not believe there was a plan in
place to ensure all case management requirements were met for
their cases. Both of the terminated staff were in management but
also had cases assigned to them.
Executive Director of Foster Care & Licensing was
interviewed via telephone on November 14, 2024. She stated
the agency has procedures in place to ensure all case
requirements are being met. There are weekly meetings with
supervisors to review the Book of Business to assess any
outstanding Key Performance Indicators including home visits.
The agency expectation is for home visits to be completed by the
25th of each month. If that isn’t completed, she will follow up with
the supervisor on the cases that are still missing required home
visits.
The agency oversees approximately 146 cases and employs 10
foster care workers and 3 supervisors. She stated there were two
staff who left abruptly at the request of the agency on October 22,
2024. She clarified the reason for their departure was not due to
performance issues and there were no previous concerns
regarding case activities not being completed as required. One of
the staff was a director and the other was a supervisor and both
had cases assigned to them at the time of their departure.
Executive Director of Foster Care & Licensing stated she
completed the face-to-face requirements in October 2024 for all of
the youth on departed staff’s caseload with the exception of Youth
2

J. She stated the contact information was not up to date and she
made a few attempts to complete an unannounced visit, but was
not successful. She mailed Youth J a letter and was able to
successfully complete a face-to-face visit on November 5, 2024.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case files for Youth A-J were reviewed as these
youth were apart of the caseloads for the recently departed
staff members.
Youth A: Face-to-face contact made in caregiver’s home on
10/31/2024.
Youth B: Face-to-face contact made in caregiver’s home on
10/29/2024.
Youth C, D, E, F & G: Face-to-face contact made in
caregiver’s home on 10/28/2024.
Youth H & I: Fac-to-face contact made in caregiver’s home
on 10/30/2024.
Youth J: Face-to-face contact not made in October 2024.
Made on 11/5/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of case information in MISACWIS there was
not a home visit completed with Youth J in the placement for the
month of October 2024 as required.
Conclusion Violation Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
______________11/15/2024______________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
11/15/2024
